revision.comment: Added free to read link in citations with [[WP:OABOT|OAbot]] #oabot
revision.text:
{{about|the economic theory of incomplete contracts|legal definitions and contract law|Contract}} In economic theory, the field of [[contract theory]] can be subdivided in the theory of [[complete contract]]s and the theory of '''incomplete contracts'''.
The incomplete contracting paradigm was pioneered by [[Sanford J. Grossman]], [[Oliver Hart (economist)|Oliver D. Hart]], and [[John Hardman Moore|John H. Moore]]. In their seminal contributions, Grossman and Hart (1986), Hart and Moore (1990), and Hart (1995) argue that in practice, contracts cannot specify what is to be done in every possible contingency.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = The costs and benefits of ownership: A theory of vertical and lateral integration|last = Grossman|first = Sanford J.|date = 1986|journal = Journal of Political Economy|doi = 10.1086/261404|pmid = |last2 = Hart|first2 = Oliver D.|pages = 691–719|volume = 94}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Property Rights and the Nature of the Firm|last = Hart|first = Oliver D.|date = 1990|journal = Journal of Political Economy|doi = 10.1086/261729|pmid = |last2 = Moore|first2 = John|pages = 1119–58|volume = 98}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Firms, Contracts, and Financial Structure|last = Hart|first = Oliver|publisher = Oxford University Press|year = 1995|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> At the time of contracting, future contingencies may not even be describable. Moreover, parties cannot commit themselves never to engage in mutually beneficial renegotiation later on in their relationship. Thus, an immediate consequence of the incomplete contracting approach is the so-called [[hold-up problem]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Hold-Up Problem and Incomplete Contracts: A Survey of Recent Topics in Contract Theory|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1467-8586.00114/abstract|journal = Bulletin of Economic Research|date = 2001|issn = 1467-8586|pages = 1–17|volume = 53|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/1467-8586.00114|first = Patrick W.|last = Schmitz}}</ref> Since at least in some states of the world the parties will renegotiate their contractual arrangements later on, they have insufficient incentives to make relationship-specific investments (since a party's investment returns will partially go to the other party in the renegotiations). Oliver Hart and his co-authors argue that the hold-up problem may be mitigated by choosing a suitable ownership structure ex ante (according to the incomplete contracting paradigm, more complex contractual arrangements are ruled out). Hence, the property rights approach to the [[theory of the firm]] can explain the pros and cons of vertical integration, thus providing a formal answer to important questions regarding the boundaries of the firm that were first raised by [[Ronald Coase]] (1937).<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Nature of the Firm|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-0335.1937.tb00002.x/abstract|journal = Economica|date = 1937|issn = 1468-0335|pages = 386–405|volume = 4|issue = 16|doi = 10.1111/j.1468-0335.1937.tb00002.x|first = R. H.|last = Coase}}</ref>
The incomplete contracting approach has been subject of a still ongoing discussion in contract theory. In particular, some authors such as Maskin and Tirole (1999) argue that rational parties should be able to solve the [[hold-up problem]] with complex contracts, while Hart and Moore (1999) point out that these contractual solutions do not work if renegotiation cannot be ruled out.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Unforeseen Contingencies and Incomplete Contracts|url = http://restud.oxfordjournals.org/content/66/1/83|journal = The Review of Economic Studies|date = 1999|issn = 0034-6527|pages = 83–114|volume = 66|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/1467-937X.00079|first = Eric|last = Maskin|first2 = Jean|last2 = Tirole}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Foundations of Incomplete Contracts|url = http://restud.oxfordjournals.org/content/66/1/115|journal = The Review of Economic Studies|date = 1999|issn = 0034-6527|pages = 115–138|volume = 66|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/1467-937X.00080|first = Oliver|last = Hart|first2 = John|last2 = Moore}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Incomplete Contracts: Where do We Stand?|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1468-0262.00052/abstract|journal = Econometrica|date = 1999|issn = 1468-0262|pages = 741–781|volume = 67|issue = 4|doi = 10.1111/1468-0262.00052|first = Jean|last = Tirole}}</ref> Some authors have argued that the pros and cons of vertical integration can sometimes also be explained in complete contracting models.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 4135244|title = Allocating Control in Agency Problems with Limited Liability and Sequential Hidden Actions|last = Schmitz|first = Patrick W.|date = 2005|journal = RAND Journal of Economics|doi = |pmid = |volume = 36|pages = 318–336}}</ref> The property rights approach based on incomplete contracting has been criticized by Williamson (2000) because it is focused on ex ante investment incentives, while it neglects ex post inefficiencies.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The New Institutional Economics: Taking Stock, Looking Ahead|url = http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/abs/10.1257/jel.38.3.595|journal = Journal of Economic Literature|date = 2000|issn = 0022-0515|pages = 595–613|volume = 38|issue = 3|doi = 10.1257/jel.38.3.595|first = Oliver E|last = Williamson}}</ref> It has been pointed out by Schmitz (2006) that the property rights approach can be extended to the case of asymmetric information, which may explain ex post inefficiencies.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Information Gathering, Transaction Costs, and the Property Rights Approach|url = http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/abs/10.1257/000282806776157722|journal = American Economic Review|date = 2006|issn = 0002-8282|pages = 422–434|volume = 96|issue = 1|doi = 10.1257/000282806776157722|first = Patrick W|last = Schmitz}}</ref> The property rights approach has also been extended by Chiu (1998) and DeMeza and Lockwood (1998), who allow for different ways to model the renegotiations.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 117010|title = Noncooperative Bargaining, Hostages, and Optimal Asset Ownership|last = Chiu|first = Y. Stephen|date = 1998|journal = American Economic Review|doi = |pmid = |pages = 882–901|volume = 88}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Does Asset Ownership Always Motivate Managers? Outside Options and the Property Rights Theory of the Firm|url = http://qje.oxfordjournals.org/content/113/2/361|journal = The Quarterly Journal of Economics|date = 1998|issn = 0033-5533|pages = 361–386|volume = 113|issue = 2|doi = 10.1162/003355398555621|first = David de|last = Meza|first2 = Ben|last2 = Lockwood}}</ref> In a more recent extension, Hart and Moore (2008) have argued that contracts may serve as reference points.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 25098893|title = Contracts as Reference Points|last = Hart|first = Oliver|date = 2008|journal = Quarterly Journal of Economics|doi = 10.1162/qjec.2008.123.1.1|pmid = |volume = 123|pages = 1–48|last2 = Moore|first2 = John}}</ref> The theory of incomplete contracts has been successfully applied in various contexts, including privatization,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Proper Scope of Government: Theory and an Application to Prisons|url = http://qje.oxfordjournals.org/content/112/4/1127|journal = The Quarterly Journal of Economics|date = 1997|issn = 0033-5533|pages = 1127–1161|volume = 112|issue = 4|doi = 10.1162/003355300555448|first = Oliver|last = Hart|first2 = Andrei|last2 = Shleifer|first3 = Robert W.|last3 = Vishny}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Public versus private ownership: Quantity contracts and the allocation of investment tasks|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047272709001492|journal = Journal of Public Economics|date = 2010|pages = 258–268|volume = 94|issue = 3–4|doi = 10.1016/j.jpubeco.2009.11.009|first = Eva I.|last = Hoppe|first2 = Patrick W.|last2 = Schmitz}}</ref> international trade,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Offshoring and the Role of Trade Agreements|url = http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/abs/10.1257/aer.102.7.3140|journal = American Economic Review|date = 2012|issn = 0002-8282|pages = 3140–3183|volume = 102|issue = 7|doi = 10.1257/aer.102.7.3140|first = Pol|last = Antràs|first2 = Robert W|last2 = Staiger}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Protection and International Sourcing*|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-0297.2011.02462.x/abstract|journal = The Economic Journal|date = 2012|issn = 1468-0297|pages = 26–63|volume = 122|issue = 559|doi = 10.1111/j.1468-0297.2011.02462.x|first = Emanuel|last = Ornelas|first2 = John L.|last2 = Turner}}</ref> management of research & development,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Management of Innovation|url = http://qje.oxfordjournals.org/content/109/4/1185|journal = The Quarterly Journal of Economics|date = 1994|issn = 0033-5533|pages = 1185–1209|volume = 109|issue = 4|doi = 10.2307/2118360|first = Philippe|last = Aghion|first2 = Jean|last2 = Tirole}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Optimal allocation of ownership rights in dynamic R&D alliances|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0899825602005535|journal = Games and Economic Behavior|date = 2003|pages = 153–173|volume = 43|issue = 1|doi = 10.1016/S0899-8256(02)00553-5|first = Stephanie|last = Rosenkranz|first2 = Patrick W.|last2 = Schmitz}}</ref> allocation of formal and real authority,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Formal and Real Authority in Organizations|url = http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/262063|journal = Journal of Political Economy|date = 1997|issn = 0022-3808|pages = 1–29|volume = 105|issue = 1|doi = 10.1086/262063|first = Philippe|last = Aghion|first2 = Jean|last2 = Tirole|citeseerx = 10.1.1.558.3199}}</ref> advocacy,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Advocates|jstor = 10.1086/250049|journal = Journal of Political Economy|volume = 107|issue = 1|doi = 10.1086/250049|first = Mathias|last = Dewatripont|first2 = Jean|last2 = Tirole|pages = 1–39|date = 1999}}</ref> and many others.
The Nobel Prize in Economics 2016 was awarded to [[Oliver Hart (economist)|Oliver D. Hart]] and [[Bengt Holmström]] for their contribution to contract theory, including incomplete contracts.<ref>https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economic-sciences/laureates/2016/press.html</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Economic theories]]

revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "American physician" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|American physician}} '''John Roland Darsee''' (born {{circa|1948}} in [[Huntington, West Virginia]]) is an American [[physician]] and former [[medical research]]er. After compiling an impressive list of publications in reputable [[scientific journal]]s, he was found to have [[scientific misconduct|fabricated data]] for his publications.
==Education and research career== John Darsee obtained his [[undergraduate education]] at the [[University of Notre Dame]], then went to medical school at [[Indiana University]], where he received a degree in 1974.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.h2mw.eu/redactionmedicale/2012/02/Darsee%20J%20Am%20Soc%20Information%20Science.pdf |title=The Persistence of fraud in the literature: The Darsee case |journal=[[Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology]] |date=August 1992 |first1=Carol Ann |last1=Kochan| first2=John M. |last2=Budd |volume=43 |number=7 |pages=488–93}}</ref>
Darsee had an excellent reputation as a student and medical researcher. He worked at [[Emory University]] from 1974 to 1979, serving as [[resident (medicine)|chief medical resident]] at [[Grady Memorial Hospital]].<ref name="time"/> He then moved to [[Harvard University]], where he worked as [[research fellow]] at the Cardiac Research Laboratory. Darsee produced 5 [[Academic publishing|major papers]] in his first 15 months at Harvard.<ref name="time">{{cite news |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,955142-1,00.html |title= Fraud in a Harvard lab |first= Claudia |last= Wallis |magazine= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date= February 28, 1983 |accessdate= March 4, 2008}}</ref> The head of his lab, [[cardiologist]] [[Eugene Braunwald]], considered Darsee the most remarkable of the 130 fellows who had worked in his lab and offered Darsee a [[Faculty (academic staff)|faculty position]] at Harvard in 1981. Some of Darsee's colleagues became concerned about the accuracy of Darsee's results. They went to the lab director, Robert Kroner, with their suspicions. Kroner investigated and found that Darsee had been altering dates on his laboratory work to make a few hours' work appear to be several weeks of data.<ref name="time"/> When informed, Braunwald terminated Darsee's fellowship but did not inform the [[National Institutes of Health]] (NIH), which was funding the research, of Darsee's misconduct at the time.<ref name="time"/>
Braunwald and Kroner conducted their own investigation into Darsee's work and found no other evidence of fraud; nor did a committee of Harvard faculty appointed by the Dean of the medical school.<ref name="nejm">{{cite journal |last=Dingell |first=John D. |authorlink=John Dingell |title=Shattuck Lecture--Misconduct in medical research |journal= [[The New England Journal of Medicine]] |volume=328 |issue=22 |pages=1610–5 |year=1993 |pmid=8487803 |doi=10.1056/NEJM199306033282207}}</ref> However, in October 1981 discrepancies between Darsee's data and those collected by other centers performing similar work triggered a formal investigation by the NIH.<ref name="time"/> The NIH review found that Darsee had committed wide-ranging [[scientific misconduct]], [[Fabrication (science)|fabricating]] large amounts of data from [[experiment]]s which he had never conducted. Harvard's investigation, as well as that of Braunwald and Kroner, were criticized for being inadequately rigorous and for reporting that they had "fully reviewed" data which later turned out to be non-existent.<ref name="nejm"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medico-legalsociety.org.uk/articles/dishonesty_in_medical_research.pdf |title=Dishonesty in Medical Research |first=Peter |last=Wilmshurst |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521050439/http://www.medico-legalsociety.org.uk/articles/dishonesty_in_medical_research.pdf |archivedate=2013-05-21 |df= }}</ref> Darsee was barred by the NIH from receiving federal [[Funding of science|research funding]] for 10 years.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite news |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A01E4DF153BF937A25755C0A965948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=1 |title= Notorious Darsee case shakes assumptions about science |first= William J. |last= Broad |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |date= June 14, 1983 |accessdate= March 4, 2008}}</ref> [[Brigham and Women's Hospital]], affiliated with Harvard, had to return $122,371 in research funds to NIH. This was the first time an institution was required to return money to NIH because of research fraud.<ref name="Harris2013">{{cite book |last= Harris |first= Charles E., Jr. |title= Engineering Ethics: Concepts and Cases |year= 2013 |publisher= Cengage Learning|isbn=1133934684 |pages= [https://books.google.com/books?id=B3sqYcyV-DkC&pg=PA223 223–4]}}</ref>
==Wider misconduct== Over time, more research by Darsee came under fire. Investigations revealed that Darsee had previously used false data between 1966 and 1970, while an undergraduate at the [[University of Notre Dame]]. Following the NIH investigation, Harvard [[Retraction|retracted]] 30 of Darsee's papers and [[Abstract (summary)|abstracts]] in February 1983. Review of Darsee's earlier work at Emory University led to the retraction of an additional 52 papers and abstracts published during his tenure there.<ref name="time"/> Braunwald drew criticism for lax supervision and for creating "a hurried pace and emphasis on productivity, coupled with limited interaction with senior scientists", which contributed to the ease with which Darsee was able to fabricate data.<ref name="time"/><ref name="nytimes"/> [[Arnold Relman]], editor of ''[[The New England Journal of Medicine]]'', also criticized Darsee's coauthors for their unfamiliarity with his work and lack of awareness of the scientific misconduct.<ref name="relman">{{cite journal |last=Relman |first= AS |title=Lessons from the Darsee affair |journal=[[The New England Journal of Medicine]] |volume=308 |issue=23 |pages=1415–7 |year=1983 |pmid=6843634 |doi=10.1056/NEJM198306093082311}}</ref>
==Aftermath== Darsee maintained that he had "no recollection" of committing research fraud.<ref name="time"/> He issued an apology which was printed in ''The New England Journal of Medicine'', writing: "I am deeply sorry for allowing these inaccuracies and falsehoods to be published in the Journal and apologize to the editorial board and readers." Darsee asked "forgiveness for whatever I have done wrong."<ref name="time"/><ref name="apology">{{cite journal |last=Darsee |first= JR |title=A retraction of two papers on cardiomyopathy |journal=[[The New England Journal of Medicine]] |volume=308 |issue=23 |page=1419 |year=1983 |pmid=6341850 |doi=10.1056/NEJM198306093082313}}</ref>
Darsee subsequently entered a clinical fellowship in [[intensive-care medicine|critical care]] at Ellis Hospital in [[Schenectady, New York]].<ref name="time"/> He worked there until June 1983. In 1984 the [[New York State Board of Regents]] revoked his [[Medical license|license to practice medicine]] in the state of New York.<ref name=CrimsonLicense>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1984/9/28/fraudulent-harvard-researcher-loses-medical-practice/?print=1 |title=Fraudulent Harvard researcher loses medical practice license |newspaper=[[The Harvard Crimson]] |date=September 28, 1984}}</ref> He is now working as a medical writer and blogger under the name of John Hughes-Darsee and living with his wife, Linda Hughes, a surgical nurse, and 2 children in West Nyack, NY. <ref name=CrimsonLicense/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://richardstein.blogspot.com/2013_02_01_archive.html |title=Academic Fraud |work=No Cause for Shame |type=blog |date=February 6, 2013 |first=Richard |last=Stein }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.doximity.com/pub/john-darsee-md |title=John Darsee, MD; Internal Medicine; Indianapolis, IN |publisher=Doximity.com |accessdate=August 8, 2013}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of scientific misconduct incidents]]
== Footnotes == {{reflist}}
==References== *{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/20/science/20rese.html?ex=1175572800&en=99ae85a0f20ed40f&ei=5070 |title= Global trend: More science, more fraud |newspaper= New York Times |date= 2005-12-20}} *{{cite news |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=9B0DEFDA1F30F936A25752C0A961948260 |title= Study accusing researcher of inaccuracies is published |newspaper= New York Times |date= 1987-01-15 |last= Boffey |first= Philip M.}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Darsee, John}} [[Category:Scientific misconduct]] [[Category:1940s births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Physicians from New York (state)]] [[Category:University of Notre Dame alumni]] [[Category:Emory University faculty]] [[Category:Harvard University faculty]] [[Category:Indiana University School of Medicine alumni]]

revision.text:
{{redirect|Launch Complex 39|the Proton launch complex at Baikonur|Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 200}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox launch pad |name = Launch Complex 39 |image =VAB Aerial - GPN-2000-000869.jpg |caption = Aerial view of Launch Complex 39, showing the [[Vehicle Assembly Building]] (front), and launch pads 39B (back left) and 39A (back right) |site = [[Kennedy Space Center]] |location = {{coord|28|36|30.2|N|80|36|15.6|W|type:landmark_region:US}} |short = LC-39 |operator =[[NASA]] |tlaunches = '''168''' (13 Saturn V, 4 Saturn IB, 135 Shuttle, 1 Ares I, 14 Falcon 9, 1 Falcon Heavy)<!-- UPDATE after each launch --> |pads = 3 |inclination = 28°–62° | paddetails = {{Infobox launch pad/pad | designation = Pad 39A | status = under upgrades and construction for SpaceX crew Dragon | launches = '''109''' (12 Saturn V, 82 Shuttle, 14 Falcon 9, 1 Falcon Heavy)<!-- UPDATE after each launch --> | unknown = | first_launch = November 9, 1967 |first_details = [[Saturn V]] / [[Apollo 4]] | last_launch = November 15, 2018 |last_details = [[Falcon 9]] / [[Es'hail 2]]<!-- UPDATE after each launch --> | rockets = {{flatlist| * [[Saturn V]] (retired) * [[Space Shuttle]] (retired) * [[Falcon 9]] (current) * [[Falcon Heavy]] (current) * [[BFR (rocket)|BFR]] (future) }} }} {{Infobox launch pad/pad | designation = Pad 39B | status = Facility modifications underway for mid 2020 [[Space Launch System|SLS]] launch | launches = '''59''' (1 Saturn V, 4 Saturn IB, 53 Shuttle, 1 Ares I-X) | first_launch = May 18, 1969 |first_details = [[Saturn V]] / [[Apollo 10]] | last_launch = October 28, 2009 |last_details = [[Ares I-X]] | rockets = {{flatlist| * [[Saturn IB]] (retired) * [[Saturn V]] (retired) * [[Space Shuttle]] (retired) * [[Ares I-X]] (cancelled) * [[Space Launch System]] (future) * [[OmegA]] (future) }} }} {{Infobox launch pad/pad | designation = Pad 39C | status = Completed June 2015 | launches = To be determined | first_launch = | last_launch = | rockets = [[Electron (rocket)|Electron]] }} }} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Launch Complex 39 | nrhp_type = | image = | caption = | location= John F. Kennedy Space Center, [[Titusville, Florida]] | locmapin = Florida#USA | built = 1967 | added = May 24, 1973 | area = {{convert|7000|acre}} | governing_body = Federal | mpsub = {{NRHP url|id=64500111|title=John F. Kennedy Space Center MPS}} | refnum = 73000568<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> }}
'''Launch Complex 39 (LC-39)''' is a [[rocket launch site]] at the [[John F. Kennedy Space Center]] on [[Merritt Island, Florida|Merritt Island]] in [[Florida]], United States. The site and its collection of facilities were originally built for the [[Apollo program]], and later modified for the [[Space Shuttle program]]. As of 2017, only Launch Complex 39A is active, launching [[SpaceX]]'s [[Falcon 9]] and [[Falcon Heavy]]. Pad 39B is being modified to launch NASA's [[Space Launch System]]. A new, smaller pad, 39C was added in 2015 to support smaller launches but has not yet been used.
Launch Complex 39 is composed of three launch pads—[[#Launch Pad 39A|39A]], [[#Launch Pad 39B|39B]] and [[#Launch Pad 39C|39C]], a [[Vehicle Assembly Building]] (VAB), a [[Crawlerway]] used by [[crawler-transporter]]s to carry [[Mobile Launcher Platform]]s between the VAB and the pads, [[Orbiter Processing Facility]] buildings, a [[Launch Control Center]] which contains the firing rooms, a [[Launch Complex 39 Press Site|news facility]] famous for the iconic countdown clock seen in television coverage and photos, and various logistical and operational support buildings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/facilities/tour.html|title=KSC Facilities|publisher=NASA|accessdate=2009-07-06}}</ref>
SpaceX leases Launch Pad 39A from NASA and has modified the pad to support Falcon Heavy launches in 2017 and beyond.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/9/6/9270317/spacex-falcon-heavy-rocket-scheduled-launch-spring-2016|title=After delays, SpaceX's massive Falcon Heavy rocket set to launch in spring 2016|author=Dante D'Orazio|date=6 September 2015|publisher=Vox Media|work=The Verge}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://spacenews.com/spacex-seeks-to-accelerate-falcon-9-production-and-launch-rates-this-year/|title=Spacex seeks to accelerate falcon 9 production and launch rates this year|date=4 February 2016}}</ref> [[NASA]] began modifying Launch Pad 39B in 2007 to accommodate the now defunct [[Project Constellation]], and is currently preparing it for the [[Space Launch System]]<ref name="pad1">{{cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/facilities/lc39a.html|title= Launch Complex 39-A & 39-B |accessdate=September 30, 2007|publisher=[[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]]|year=1993|author=[[NASA]]}}</ref><ref name="pad2">{{Cite web|url=http://www-pao.ksc.nasa.gov/kscpao/nasafact/pads.htm|title=Launch Complex 39|accessdate=September 30, 2007|publisher=NASA|year=2000|author=NASA|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927112326/http://www-pao.ksc.nasa.gov/kscpao/nasafact/pads.htm|archivedate=September 27, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> with first launch scheduled for December 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-completes-review-of-first-sls-orion-deep-space-exploration-mission|title=NASA Completes Review of First SLS, Orion Deep Space Exploration Mission|publisher=}}</ref> Pad C was originally planned for Apollo but never built, and would have been a copy of pads 39A and 39B. A smaller pad, designated 39C was constructed from January to June 2015 to accommodate [[Small-lift launch vehicle|small-class vehicles.]]<ref name="lc39C" />
NASA launches from LC-39A and 39B have been supervised from the NASA [[Launch Control Center]] (LCC), located {{convert|3|mi|km}} from the launch pads. LC-39 is one of several launch sites that share radar and tracking services of the [[Eastern Test Range]].
==History==
===Early history=== Northern Merritt Island was first developed around 1890 when a few wealthy Harvard University graduates purchased {{convert|18000|acre|km2}} and constructed a three-story mahogany clubhouse, very nearly on the site of Pad 39A.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ngs.noaa.gov/cgi-bin/ds_mark.prl?PidBox=AK6126|title=NGS DATASHEET FOR CLUBHOUSE SOUTHWEST GABLE|publisher=National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)|accessdate=2013-01-20}}</ref> During the 1920s, Peter E. Studebaker Jr., son of [[Studebaker|the automobile magnate]], built a small casino at De Soto Beach eight miles (13 km) north of the Canaveral lighthouse.<ref>Eriksen, John M. [http://johneriksen.net/bc/bc_cb.htm ''Brevard County, Florida : A Short History to 1955'']. See Chapter Ten on De Soto Grove, De Soto Beach, and Playa Linda Beach.</ref>
In 1948, the Navy transferred the former Banana River Naval Air Station located south of [[Cape Canaveral]], to the Air Force for use in testing captured German V-2 rockets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.patrick.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=4514 |title=EVOLUTION OF THE 45TH SPACE WING |publisher=US Air Force |accessdate=2009-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613181155/http://www.patrick.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=4514 |archivedate=June 13, 2011 |df= }}</ref> The site's location on the East Florida coast was ideal for this purpose in that launches would be over the ocean, away from populated areas. This site became the Joint Long Range Proving Ground in 1949, and was renamed [[Patrick Air Force Base]] in 1950. The Air Force annexed part of Cape Canaveral to the North in 1951, forming the Air Force Missile Test Center, the future [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]] (CCAFS). Missile and rocketry testing and development would take place here through the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spaceline.org/capehistory/2a.html|title=THE HISTORY OF CAPE CANAVERAL CHAPTER 2: THE MISSILE RANGE TAKES SHAPE (1949–1958)|publisher=Spaceline.org|accessdate=2009-07-06}}</ref>
After the [[creation of NASA]] in 1958, the CCAFS launch pads were used for NASA's civilian unmanned and manned launches, including those of [[Project Mercury]] and [[Project Gemini]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/sites/capallc5.htm|title=Cape Canaveral LC5|publisher=Astronautix.com|accessdate=2009-07-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414180519/http://www.astronautix.com/sites/capallc5.htm|archivedate=April 14, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== Apollo and Skylab === {{Main|Apollo program}} In 1961, President Kennedy proposed to Congress the goal of landing a man on the Moon by the end of the decade. Congressional approval led to the launch of the [[Apollo program]], which required a massive expansion of NASA operations, including an expansion of launch operations from the Cape to adjacent Merritt Island to the north and west.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spaceline.org/capehistory/3a.html|title=THE HISTORY OF CAPE CANAVERAL CHAPTER 3 NASA ARRIVES (1959–PRESENT)|publisher=Spaceline.org|accessdate=2009-07-06}}</ref> NASA began acquisition of land in 1962, taking title to {{convert|131|sqmi}} by outright purchase and negotiating with the state of Florida for an additional {{convert|87|sqmi}}. On July 1, 1962, the site was named the '''Launch Operations Center'''.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.nasa.gov/centers/kennedy/about/information/visitor_faq.html#29 | title = Kennedy Space Center Visitor and Area Information | NASA | accessdate = February 11, 2017 }}</ref>
====Initial design==== {{multiple image |direction=horizontal |align=right |total_width=550 |image1=Lc39 plan 1963 labelled.png |width1=658 |height1=494 |caption1=Launch Complex Plan – 1963 |image2=Lc39 warning lamps.jpg |width2=1107 |height2=1410 |caption2=Warning lamps for the planned 3 pads, including the unbuilt pad C }}
At the time, the highest numbered launch pad on CCAFS was Launch Complex 37; when the lunar launch complex was designed, it was designated as Launch Complex 39. It was designed to handle launches of the [[Saturn V]] rocket, the largest, most powerful rocket then designed, which would propel Apollo spacecraft to the Moon. Initial plans included four pads (five were considered) evenly spaced {{convert|8700|ft|m}} apart to avoid damage in the event of an explosion on the pad. Three were scheduled for construction (A-C, to the southeast) and two (D and E, west and north) would have been built at a later date. The numbering of the pads at the time was from north to south, with the northernmost being 39A, and the southernmost being 39C. Pad 39A was never built, and 39C became 39A in 1963. With today's numbering, 39C would have been north of 39B, and 39D would have been due west of 39C. Pad 39E would have been due north of the mid-distance between 39C and 39D, with 39E forming the top of a triangle, and equidistant from 39C and 39D. The [[Crawlerway]] was built with the additional pads in mind. This is the reason the Crawlerway turns as it heads to Pad B; continuing straight from that turn would have led to the additional pads.<ref>{{Cite book |last = Petrone |first = Rocco A. |author-link = Rocco Petrone |editor-last = Cortright |editor-first = Edgar M. |editor-link = Edgar Cortright |date = 1975 |chapter = Chapter 6: The Cape |chapter-url = https://history.nasa.gov/SP-350/ch-6-1.html |title = Apollo Expeditions to the Moon |url = https://history.nasa.gov/SP-350/cover.html |publisher = Scientific and Technical Information Office, [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] |place = Washington, DC |id = SP-350 }}</ref>
==== Integration of space vehicle stack ==== {{Main|Vehicle Assembly Building}} {{multiple image |direction=vertical |align=right |total_width=280 |image1=69-HC-620 - SA506.jpg |width1=1200 |height1=917 |caption1=Apollo-Saturn 506 with [[Apollo 11]] spacecraft being moved from the VAB to LC39A (1969) |image2=Crawler-Transporter.jpg |width2=3000 |height2=1993 |caption2=A restored Crawler-Transporter (2004) }} Months before launch, the three stages of the [[Saturn V]] launch vehicle and the components of the [[Apollo spacecraft]] were brought inside the Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB) and assembled in one of four high bays into a {{convert|363|ft|m|adj=on}}-tall space vehicle on one of three [[Mobile Launcher Platform|Mobile Launcher]]s. Each mobile launcher consisted of a two-story, {{convert|49|by|41|m|ft|adj=on|order=flip}} launch platform with four hold-down arms and a {{convert|136|m|ft|adj=on|order=flip|sp=us}} Launch Umbilical Tower (LUT) topped by a crane used to lift the spacecraft into position for assembly. The MLP and unfueled vehicle together weighed {{convert|12600000|lb|MT|sigfig=4}}.<ref name="Moonport_appendixb">{{cite book | last1 = Benson | first1 = Charles D. | last2 = Faherty | first2 = William B. | authorlink = | title = Moonport: A History of Apollo Launch Facilities and Operations | publisher = NASA | series = History Series | volume = SP-4204 | edition = | date=August 1977 | location = | pages = | url = http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4204/contents.html | chapter = Appendix B: Launch Complex 39 | chapterurl = https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4204/appendixb.pdf | doi = | id = | isbn = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref>
The Umbilical Tower contained two elevators and nine retractable swing arms which extended to the space vehicle, to provide access to each of the three rocket stages and the spacecraft for people, wiring and plumbing while the vehicle was on the launch pad, and swung away from the vehicle at launch.<ref name="Moonport_appendixb"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Swing Arm Engineer|url=http://enterfiringroom.ksc.nasa.gov/systemSwingArm.htm|publisher=NASA|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101107093952/http://enterfiringroom.ksc.nasa.gov/systemSwingArm.htm|archivedate=November 7, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Technicians, engineers, and astronauts used the uppermost Spacecraft Access Arm to access the crew cabin. At the end of the arm, the [[white room (spacecraft)|white room]] provided an environmentally controlled and protected area for astronauts and their equipment to enter the spacecraft.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/technology/sts-newsref/sts-lc39.html | title = LAUNCH COMPLEXES 39-A AND 39-B | access-date = February 11, 2017}} </ref>
==== Transportation to the pad ==== When the stack integration was completed, it was moved the {{convert|3|–|4|mi|km}} to the pad at a speed of {{convert|1|mph|kph}} by one of two [[Crawler-Transporter]]s. Each crawler weighed {{convert|2720|MT|lb|order=flip}} and was capable of keeping the space vehicle on its Mobile Launcher level while negotiating a 5 percent grade to the pad. At the pad, the MLP was supported by six steel pedestals, plus four additional extensible columns.<ref name="Moonport_appendixb"/>
==== Mobile Service Structure ==== [[File:Saturn V and service structures.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.9|[[Saturn V]] with fixed (left) and mobile (right) service structures]] [[File:LC-39A walkway.jpg|thumb|200px|Apollo-era walkway and [[White room (spaceflight)|white room]], on display at [[Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex]]]] After the MLP was set in place, the Crawler-Transporter rolled a {{convert|125|m|ft|order=flip|adj=on|sp=us}}, {{convert|4760|MT|lb|order=flip|adj=on}} Mobile [[service structure|Service Structure]] (MSS) into place to provide further access for technicians to perform detailed checkout of the vehicle, and necessary umbillical connections to the pad. The MSS contained three elevators, two self-propelled platforms and three fixed platforms, and was rolled back {{convert|2100|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} to its parking position shortly before launch.<ref name="Moonport_appendixb"/>
==== Flame deflector ==== A flame deflector was slid on rails into place under the launch pedestal. This system allowed for rotation with a second flame deflector, after the first was refurbished after each launch. Each deflector measured {{convert|12|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} high by {{convert|15|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} wide by {{convert|23|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} long and weighed {{convert|635|MT|lb|order=flip|sp=us}}. It deflected the exhaust flame into a trench measuring {{convert|13|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} deep by {{convert|18|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} wide by {{convert|137|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} long.<ref name="Moonport_appendixb"/>
==== Launch control and fueling ==== The four-story [[Launch Control Center]] was located {{convert|5.6|km|mi|order=flip|sp=us}} away from Pad A, adjacent to the Vehicle Assembly Building for safety. The third floor had four firing rooms (corresponding to the four high bays in the VAB), each with 470 sets of control and monitoring equipment.{{when|date=April 2014}}<!-- at what time in its long history did this apply? --> The second floor contained telemetry, tracking, instrumentation, and data reduction computing equipment. The LCC was connected to the Mobile Launchers by a high speed data link, and during launch a system of 62 closed-circuit television cameras transmitted to 100 monitor screens in the LCC.<ref name="Moonport_appendixb"/>
Large cryogenic tanks located near the pads stored the liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen (LOX) for the second and third stages of the Saturn V. The highly explosive nature of these chemicals required numerous safety measures at the Launch Complex. The pads were located {{convert|2660|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} away from each other.<ref name="Moonport_appendixb"/> Before tanking operations began and during launch, non-essential personnel were excluded from the danger area.
==== Emergency evacuation system ==== Each pad had a {{convert|61|m|ft|order=flip|adj=on|sp=us}} evacuation tube running from the Mobile Launcher platform to a [[Rubber room (bunker)|blast-resistant bunker]] {{convert|12|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} underground, equipped with survival supplies for 20 persons for 24 hours. There was also a cab/slidewire system running from the {{convert|98|m|ft|order=flip|adj=on|sp=us}} tower level to evacuate astronauts and technicians {{convert|763|m|ft|order=flip|sp=us}} away from the pad.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2236512/Inside-Nasas-blast-room-The-secret-bunker-springs-protected-Apollo-era-astronauts-explosions-launch.html | title = Inside Nasa's blast room: Secret bunker on springs that would have protected Apollo astronauts in a disaster | last = Nye | first = James | date = November 21, 2012 | access-date = February 11, 2017}} </ref>
==== Pad Terminal Connection Room ==== Connections between the [[Launch Control Center]], [[mobile launcher platform]] and space vehicle are made in the Pad Terminal Connection Room (PTCR). The facility was a two-story series of rooms beneath the launch pad, constructed of reinforced concrete located on the west side of the flame trench and was protected by up to {{convert| 20|ft}} of fill dirt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/launch/pad-term-connect-room.html|title=NASA – Pad Terminal Connection Room|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Young|first=John|title=Wings in Orbit: Scientific and Engineering Legacies of the Space Shuttle 1971–2010|isbn=978-0-16-086847-4|pages=82|authorlink=John Young (astronaut)|author2=Robert Crippen }}</ref>
====Apollo and Skylab launches==== {{multiple image |direction=vertical |align=right |total_width=280 |image1=Launch Apollo4.jpg |width1=798 |height1=1024 |caption1=[[Apollo 4]], the first unmanned test flight of the [[Saturn V]], rising from pad 39A (November 1967) |image2=ASTP Launch - GPN-2000-000643.jpg |width2=3000 |height2=2400 |caption2=Final launch of [[Saturn IB]] from pad 39B, carrying the [[Apollo-Soyuz Test Project]] Command Module into orbit (July 1975) }} The first use of LC-39 came in 1967 with the first Saturn V launch, carrying the unmanned [[Apollo 4]] spacecraft. The second unmanned launch, [[Apollo 6]], also used Pad 39A. With the exception of [[Apollo 10]], which used Pad 39B (due to the "all-up" testing resulting in a 2-month turnaround period), all manned Apollo-Saturn V launches, commencing with [[Apollo 8]], used Pad 39A.
A total of thirteen Saturn Vs were launched for Apollo, and the unmanned launch of the [[Skylab]] space station in 1973. The mobile launchers were then modified for the shorter [[Saturn IB]] rockets, by adding a "milk-stool" extension platform to the launch pedestal, so that the [[S-IVB]] upper stage and Apollo spacecraft swing arms would reach. These were used for three manned Skylab flights and the [[Apollo-Soyuz Test Project]], since the Saturn IB pads 34 and 37 at Cape Canaveral AFB had been decommissioned.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://afspacemuseum.org/ccafs/CX34/ | title = Launch Complex 34 | access-date = February 11, 2017}} </ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://afspacemuseum.org/ccafs/CX37/ | title = Launch Complex 37 | access-date = February 11, 2017}} </ref>
===Space Shuttle=== {{Main|Space Shuttle program}} The thrust to allow the Space Shuttle to achieve orbit was provided by a combination of the [[Space Shuttle Solid Rocket Booster|Solid Rocket Booster]]s (SRBs) and the [[Space Shuttle Main Engine]]s (SSMEs). The SRBs used solid propellant, hence their name. The SSMEs used a combination of [[liquid hydrogen]] and [[liquid oxygen]] (LOX) from the [[External Tank]] (ET), as the orbiter did not have internal fuel tanks for the SSMEs (they would have had to be as large as the External Tank). The SRBs arrived in segments via rail car from their manufacturing facility in [[Utah]], the External Tank arrived from its manufacturing facility in [[Louisiana]] by barge, and the orbiter waited in the [[Orbiter Processing Facility]] (OPF). The SRBs were first stacked in the VAB, and then the External Tank was mounted between them. Then, using a massive crane, the orbiter was lowered and connected to the External Tank.
Payload to be installed at the launch pad was independently transported in a payload transportation canister then installed vertically at the Payload Changeout Room. Otherwise, payloads would have already been pre-installed at the Orbiter Processing Facility and transported within the orbiter's cargo bay.
The original structure of the pads was remodeled for the needs of the Space Shuttle, starting with Pad 39A after the last Saturn V launch, and in 1977 for Pad 39B after the [[Apollo-Soyuz Test Project]] in 1975.
<gallery mode="packed" heights="300px"> File:Columbia.sts-1.01.jpg|[[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] standing on pad 39A, ready for its first orbital flight ([[STS-1]], April 1981). The Rotating Service Structure has been rolled away in preparation for launch. File:STS-129 Atlantis Ready to Fly - edit1.jpg|The [[Space Shuttle Atlantis|Space Shuttle ''Atlantis'']] is seen on launch pad 39A at the NASA Kennedy Space Center shortly after the rotating service structure was rolled back on Nov. 15, 2009. </gallery>
==== Launch towers ==== Each pad contained a two-piece access tower system, the Fixed Service Structure (FSS) and the Rotating Service Structure (RSS). The FSS permitted access to the Shuttle via a retractable arm and a "beanie cap" to capture vented LOX from the External Tank. The RSS contained the Payload Changeout Room, which offered "clean" access to the orbiter's payload bay, protection from the elements, and protection in winds up to {{convert|60|kn|km/h}}.
The FSS on Pad 39A was constructed from most of the umbilical tower of Mobile Launcher 2, while the FSS that was on 39B was constructed from most of the umbilical tower of Mobile Launcher 3.
==== Sound suppression water system ==== A Sound Suppression Water System (SSWS) was added to protect the Space Shuttle and its payload from effects of the intense sound wave pressure generated by its engines. An elevated water tank on a {{convert|290|ft|m|adj=on}} tower near each pad stored 300,000 gallons (1.1 Megalitres) of water, which was released onto the Mobile Launcher Platform just before engine ignition.<ref name="nasa_suppression_system">{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/missions/shuttle/f_watertest.html|title=Sound Suppression System|accessdate=2007-10-22}}</ref> The water muffled the intense sound waves produced by the engines. Due to heating of the water, a large quantity of steam and water vapor was produced during launch.
====Swing arm modifications==== [[File:Launch Pad 39A KSC White Room Access Arm Walkway.jpg|thumb|200px|The doors to the White Room, which provided entry to the Shuttle crew compartment, are seen here at the end of the access arm walkway]] The Gaseous Oxygen Vent Arm positioned a hood, often called the "Beanie Cap," over the top of the External Tank (ET) nose cone during fueling.{{when|date=February 2014}}<!-- when was this modification made to the pad? --> Heated gaseous nitrogen was used there to remove the extremely cold gaseous oxygen that normally vented out of the External Tank. This prevented the formation of ice that could fall and damage the shuttle.<ref>{{cite web|title=NASA – External Tank (ET) Gaseous Oxygen Vent Arm |url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/launch/et-gaseous-O2-vent-arm.html |publisher=nasa.gov |accessdate=2016-12-09}}</ref>
The Hydrogen Vent Line Access Arm mated the External Tank (ET) [[Ground Umbilical Carrier Plate]] (GUCP) to the launch pad hydrogen vent line. The GUCP provided support for plumbing and cables, called umbilicals, that transferred fluids, gases, and electrical signals between two pieces of equipment. While the ET was being fueled, hazardous gas was vented from an internal hydrogen tank through the GUCP, out a vent line to a flare stack where it was burned off at a safe distance. Sensors at the GUCP measured gas level. The GUCP was redesigned after leaks created scrubs of [[STS-127]] and were also detected during attempts to launch [[STS-119]] and [[STS-133]].<ref>{{cite web|title=GUCP troubleshooting continues as MMT push for launch on June 17|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2009/06/sts-127-scrubbed-due-to-gucp-leak-launch-moves-to-net-june-17/|publisher=NASA Spaceflight}}</ref> The GUCP released from the ET at launch and fell away with a curtain of water sprayed across it for protection from flames.
==== Emergency pad evacuation ==== [[File:Astroescape.jpg|thumb|200px|M113 armored personnel carriers parked near LC-39]] In an emergency, the launch complex used a slidewire escape basket system for quick evacuation. Assisted by members of the closeout team, the crew would leave the orbiter and ride an emergency basket to the ground at speeds reaching up to {{convert|55|mph|km/h}}.<ref name="astronaut_rescue_drill">{{cite web|url=http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/ft_shuttle_training_041203.html|title=SPACE.com – NASA Conducts Shuttle Astronaut Rescue Drill|accessdate=2007-10-22}}</ref> From there, the crew took shelter in a bunker. A modified [[M113 Armored Personnel Carrier]] could carry injured astronauts away from the complex to safety.<ref name="astronaut_evacuation">{{cite web|url=http://quest.arc.nasa.gov/people/journals/space/lohning/|title=NASA Field Journal by Greg Lohning|accessdate=2008-11-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204045450/http://quest.arc.nasa.gov/people/journals/space/lohning/|archivedate=February 4, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
During the launch of Discovery on [[STS-124]] on May 31, 2008, the pad at LC-39A suffered extensive damage, in particular to the concrete trench used to deflect the SRB's flames.<ref name="damage">{{cite web|url=http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/080602-sts124-pad39a-damage.html#comments|title=NASA Eyes Launch Pad Damage for Next Shuttle Flight|work=Space.com}}</ref> The subsequent mishap investigation found that the damage was the result of carbonation of epoxy and corrosion of steel anchors which held the [[refractory brick]]s in the trench in place. These had been exacerbated by the fact that [[hydrochloric acid]] is an exhaust by-product of the solid rocket boosters.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://pbma.nasa.gov/docs/public/pbma/images/msm/STS-124FlameTrench_SFCS.pdf | title=Hit the Bricks | journal=System Failure Case Studies | publisher=NASA | date=August 2010 | volume=4 | issue=8 | pages=1–4 | author=Lilley, Steve K. | accessdate=July 20, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928091534/http://pbma.nasa.gov/docs/public/pbma/images/msm/STS-124FlameTrench_SFCS.pdf | archivedate=September 28, 2011 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
====Space Shuttle launches==== After the launch of [[Skylab]] in 1973, Pad 39A was reconfigured for the Space Shuttle, with shuttle launches beginning in 1981 with [[STS-1]], flown by the {{OV|102}}.<ref name="mods">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/launch/pad-mods.html|title=Shuttle-Era Pad Modifications |accessdate=September 30, 2007|publisher=NASA|year=2006|author=NASA}}</ref> After Apollo 10, Pad 39B was kept as a backup launch facility in the case of the destruction of 39A, but saw service for all three Skylab missions, the Apollo-Soyuz test flight, and a contingency Skylab Rescue flight that never became necessary. After the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project, 39B was reconfigured similarly to 39A, but due to additional modifications (mainly to allow the facility to service a modified [[Centaur (rocket)|Centaur-G]] upper stage), along with budgetary restraints, it was not ready until 1986, and the first shuttle flight to use it was [[STS-51-L]], which ended with the [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|''Challenger'' disaster]]. The first return to flight mission [[STS-26]] launched from 39B.
=== Constellation Program and Pad 39B === {{Main|Constellation program}} [[File:Ares I-X launch 08.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Ares I-X launches from LC-39B, 15:30 UTC, October 28, 2009]] The last Shuttle launch from Pad 39B was the nighttime launch of [[STS-116]] on December 9, 2006. To support the final Shuttle mission to the Hubble Space Telescope [[STS-125]] launched from Pad 39A in May 2009, ''[[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Endeavour]]'' was placed on 39B if needed to launch the [[STS-400]] rescue mission.
After the completion of [[STS-125]], 39B was converted for the single test flight of the ''Constellation Program'' [[Ares I-X]] from Pad 39B on October 28, 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2009/10/pad-39b-suffers-substantial-damage-ares-i-x-parachute-update/|title=Pad 39B suffers substantial damage from Ares I-X launch – Parachute update {{!}} NASASpaceFlight.com|website=www.nasaspaceflight.com|access-date=2016-04-15}}</ref> This program was later cancelled.
===2011–2013=== With the retirement of the Shuttle in 2011,<ref name=bw20101028>[http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/10_45/b4202066178314.htm?campaign_id=mag_Oct28&link_position=link23 NASA: Lost in Space], ''[[Business Week]]'', 2010-10-28, accessed 2010-10-31.</ref> and the cancellation of [[Constellation Program]] in 2010, the future of the LC-39 pads was uncertain. By early 2011, NASA began informal discussions on use of the pads and facilities by [[private spaceflight|private companies]] to fly missions for the commercial space market,<ref name=ft20110206> {{cite news |last=Dean|first=James |title=Up for grabs? Private companies eye KSC facilities |url=http://www.floridatoday.com/article/20110206/NEWS02/102060317/Up-for-grabs-Private-companies-eye-KSC-facilities |accessdate=2011-02-06 |newspaper=Florida Today |date=2011-02-06|quote=As the shuttle program nears retirement, KSC officials are evaluating whether other facilities that supported three decades of shuttle flights will transition to serve new vehicles or be discarded. The center is offering use of its launch pads, runway, Vehicle Assembly Building high bays, hangars and firing rooms to private companies expected to play a bigger role in NASA missions and a growing commercial space market.}}</ref> culminating in a 20-year lease agreement with SpaceX for Pad 39A.<ref name=flortoda/>
====Pad 39A==== Just like the first 24 shuttle flights, Pad 39A supported the final manifested shuttle flights, starting with [[STS-117]] in June 2007 until the retirement of the shuttle fleet in July 2011. Prior to the SpaceX lease agreement, the pad remained as it was when Atlantis launched on the final shuttle mission on July 8, 2011, complete with a [[mobile launcher platform]]. [[File:PAD 39A lease announcement.jpg|thumb|right|KSC Director [[Robert D. Cabana|Bob Cabana]] announces the signing of the pad 39A lease agreement on April 14, 2014. [[SpaceX]] COO [[Gwynne Shotwell]] stands nearby.]]
In 1997 the pad was the proposed as the site of the first machine for the film [[Contact (1997 American film)|Contact]].{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
Talks for use of the pad were underway between NASA and [[Space Florida]]—the [[State of Florida]]'s [[economic development agency]]—as early as 2011, but no deal materialized by 2012 and NASA then pursued other options for removing the pad from the Federal government inventory.<ref name=nsf20141117/>
By early 2013, NASA publicly announced that it would allow commercial launch providers to lease Pad 39A,<ref>[http://www.americaspace.com/?p=30313 "NASA not abandoning LC-39A" January 17, 2013], accessed February 7, 2013.</ref> and followed that, in May 2013, with a formal solicitation for proposals for [[private spaceflight|commercial use]] of Launch Pad 39A.<ref name=nsw20130520>[http://www.newspacewatch.com/articles/nasa-requests-proposals-for-commercial-use-of-pad-39a.html NASA requests proposals for commercial use of Pad 39A], ''NewSpace Watch'', May 20, 2013, accessed May 21, 2013.</ref> There were two competing bids for the commercial use of the launch complex.<ref name=leasedoc/> [[SpaceX]] submitted a bid for exclusive use of the launch complex, while [[Jeff Bezos]]' [[Blue Origin]] submitted a bid for shared non-exclusive use of the complex such that the launchpad would interface with multiple vehicles, and costs could be shared over the long term. One potential shared user in the Blue Origin plan was [[United Launch Alliance]].<ref name=os20130818> {{cite news |last=Matthews|first=Mark K. |title=Musk, Bezos fight to win lease of iconic NASA launchpad |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2013-08-18/news/os-fight-over-ksc-launchpad-20130818_1_spacex-elon-musk-christina-ra |accessdate=2013-08-21 |newspaper=Orlando Sentinel |date=2013-08-18 }}</ref> Prior to completion of the bid period, and prior to any public announcement by NASA of the results of the process, Blue Origin filed a protest with the [[Federal government of the United States|U.S.]] [[General Accounting Office]] (GAO) "over what it says is a plan by NASA to award an exclusive commercial lease to SpaceX for use of mothballed space shuttle launch pad 39A."<ref name=pa20130910/> NASA had planned to complete the bid award and have the pad transferred by October 1, 2013, but the protest "will delay any decision until the GAO reaches a decision, expected by mid-December."<ref name=pa20130910> {{cite news |last=Messier|first=Doug |title=Blue Origin Files Protest Over Lease on Pad 39A |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/09/09/49934/ |accessdate=2013-09-11 |newspaper=Parabolic Arc |date=2013-09-10 }}</ref> On December 12, 2013, the GAO denied the protest and sided with NASA, which argued that the solicitation contains no preference on the use of the facility as multi-use or single-use. "The [solicitation] document merely asks bidders to explain their reasons for selecting one approach instead of the other and how they would manage the facility."<ref name=pa20131212> {{cite news |last=Messier|first=Doug |title=Blue Origin Loses GAO Appeal Over Pad 39A Bid Process |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/12/12/blue-origin-loses-gao-appeal-pad-39a-bid-process/ |accessdate=2013-12-13 |newspaper=Parabolic Arc |date=2013-12-12 }}</ref>
On December 13, 2013, NASA announced that they had selected SpaceX as the new commercial tenant.<ref name=padnego>{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Stephen|title=SpaceX to begin negotiations for shuttle launch pad|url=http://spaceflightnow.com/news/n1312/13pad39a/#.UquHkWRDv_o|accessdate=December 13, 2013|newspaper=SpaceflightNow|date=December 13, 2013}}</ref> SpaceX signed the lease agreement on April 14, 2014.<ref name=flortoda>{{cite web|url=http://www.floridatoday.com/story/tech/science/space/2014/04/14/spacex-takes-over-ksc-pad-39a/7711859/|title=SpaceX takes over KSC pad 39A|last=Dean|first=James|date=April 14, 2014|publisher=Florida Today|accessdate=April 15, 2014}}</ref> SpaceX has been given a 20-year exclusive lease of Pad 39A.<ref name=leasedoc>{{cite web|url=https://prod.nais.nasa.gov/eps/eps_data/159268-OTHER-001-001.pdf|title=Selection Statement for Lease of Launch Complex 39A|date=December 12, 2013|publisher=NASA|accessdate=December 23, 2013}}</ref> SpaceX plans to launch their [[Falcon 9]] and [[Falcon Heavy]] from the pad and build a new hangar near it.<ref name=leasedoc/><ref name=flortoda/><ref name=tss20140321> {{cite AV media|people=Gwynne Shotwell |date=2014-03-21 |title=Broadcast 2212: Special Edition, interview with Gwynne Shotwell |medium=audio file |url=http://archived.thespaceshow.com/shows/2212-BWB-2014-03-21.mp3 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322013556/http://archived.thespaceshow.com/shows/2212-BWB-2014-03-21.mp3 |archivedate=March 22, 2014 |format=mp3 |time=20:00–21:10 |publisher=The Space Show |id=2212 |quote= |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Elon Musk]], CEO of SpaceX, has stated that he wants to shift most of their NASA launches to Pad 39A, including [[Commercial Resupply Services|Commercial Cargo]] and [[Commercial Crew Development|Crew]] missions to the [[International Space Station]].<ref name=padnego/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1312/12gao/#.UrhmtbSTJe4|title=GAO decision opens door for commercial lease of pad 39A|last=Clark|first=Stephen|date=December 12, 2013|publisher=Spaceflight Now|accessdate=December 23, 2013|quote=Musk said he wants to launch SpaceX's commercial cargo and crew missions to the International Space Station from launch pad 39A}}</ref>
== Launch history == === Pad 39A launches ===
